Graphical abstract The recent theoretical and experimental progresses on modification strategies to improve the intrinsic electrocatalytic activities are summarized, as well as their challenges and possible directions. Electrocatalytic water splitting driven by electrocatalysts is recognized as a promising strategy to generate clean hydrogen fuel. Searching and constructing high-efficient and low-cost electrocatalysts is vital in the practical applications of electrocatalytic water splitting. Although transition metal-based materials have been considered as promising electrocatalysts, the satisfactory activities are usually not built on the bulk materials, but strongly relying on elaborately designing these electrocatalysts. Herein, the recent theoretical and experimental progress on modification strategies to improve the intrinsic activities is summarized, especially including element doping, phase engineering, structure cooperation, interface engineering, vacancy engineering, strain engineering and self-functionalization. Finally, the future opportunities and challenges on these modification strategies are also proposed. Overall, it is anticipated that these modification strategies offer some new understandings on rationally constructing non-noble electrocatalysts for efficient electrocatalytic water splitting. Keywords Electrocatalysts Modification Intrinsic activity Active sites Transition metal 1 Introduction Owing to the rapid depletion of fossil fuels, it is vital to develop clean and alternative energy sources [1]. As the zero carbon-contained fuel, hydrogen is considered as the most promising candidate for replacing fossil fuels [2]. Now, electrocatalytic water splitting is an attractive strategy to produce hydrogen, which includes hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [3]. Owing to the sluggish kinetics, it is of great significance to explore efficient electrocatalysts to lower the overpotentials in HER and OER [4,5]. Up to now, the state-of-the-art electrocatalysts are Pt based noble metal for HER and RuO2/IrO2 based noble oxides for OER, respectively [6]. Nevertheless, the scarcity and high cost greatly hinder their widespread use. To provide a promising alternative to these noble metal-based electrocatalysts, a large number of efforts have been devoted to develop transition metal-based materials, such as oxides, hydroxides, sulfides, phosphides and selenides [7–10]. Various kinds of transition metal-based materials have been explored for electrocatalytic water splitting, which is attributed to the low cost and rich chemical states [11–13]. For example, MoS2 is demonstrated as a potential HER electrocatalyst by the experimental and calculation results [14,15]. And for OER, NiFe-layered double hydroxide (LDH) shows the superior catalytic performances comparable to commercial IrO2 or RuO2 [16,17]. Despite remarkable accomplishments of these transition metal-based materials for HER and OER, the intrinsic activity and durability of pristine electrocatalyst materials are still far from satisfactory. In general, the electrocatalytic performances are mainly relied on the number of active sites and intrinsic activity of each site [18,19]. Thus, the satisfactory activities are strongly relying on elaborately designing these electrocatalysts. Many strategies about nanostructure design are provided to achieve more active sites, resulting in better performances [20–22]. To further promote the intrinsic activities of these candidates, diverse modification strategies have been explored, such as element doping, phase engineering, structure cooperation, interface engineering, vacancy engineering, strain engineering and self-functionalization [23–28]. In recent years, the potential of these modification strategies is gained ever-increasing attention. Therefore, it is important to offer a review on the recent theoretical and experimental progress of these modification strategies about how to achieve better electrocatalytic performances. In this review, we mainly focus on the modification strategies for improving the intrinsic activities and summarize the recent theoretical and experimental progress. As shown in Fig. 1 , the current modification strategies are primarily discussed. Finally, we also discuss the challenges and prospects for these modification strategies on designing highly efficient electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. 2 The fundamental of water splitting mechanism The water splitting reaction can be divided into two half reactions, which are hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Both cathode and anode electrode reactions are accompanied by the electron transfer process between electrode and solution, and there may be in-situ conversion of surface species in OER [29]. Water splitting reactions contain the continuous diffusion process of H2O molecules and its intermediates, accompanied by a series of electron transfer processes. That is, the continuous adsorption and desorption of reactants on the surface of catalysts lead to the evolution of hydrogen and oxygen. Specifically, HER is mainly a two-electron transfer process [29]. The adsorption reaction on the surface is divided into two steps, taking alkaline solution as an example [5]: (1–1) Volmer : H 2 O + M + e - → MH + OH - Tafel: MH + MH → H2 + 2 M (1–2) Heyrovsky : H 2 O + MH + e - → H 2 + M + OH - The main energy barrier of HER is derived from the adsorption energy of the intermediate species in each step of the reaction process. While OER has a more complex four-electron transfer process, taking alkaline solution as an example [5]: (1–3) M + OH - → MOH + e - (1–4) OH - + MOH → H 2 O + MO + e - (1–5) MO + OH - → MOOH + e - MOOH + OH– → MOO– + H2O (1–6) MOO - → M + O 2 + e - The complexity of intermediate species and interface reactions in OER is higher than those in HER. Thus, for double electrode electrolyzer towards overall water splitting, the kinetics behaviors of OER have a more obvious effect on the total performance. In short, although the theoretical potential is 1.23 V for overall water splitting, the actual potential is much higher than the theoretical value because of the unavoidable reaction energy barrier. The use of high-performance catalysts could improve the adsorption energy of each step, thereby improving the performance of water splitting. Concretely, as for HER, the adsorption of the intermediate species on the catalyst surface is due to the pairing of atomic electron orbitals to form adsorption bonds. For example, the transition group metals have unpaired 3d electrons in the outer layer, which is easy to bond with the 1s orbital of H in HER reaction [30]. Considering that the hydrogen molecule needs to escape from the surface of catalyst, the desorption energy of the intermediate species should not be too high after adsorption bonding. That is, the adsorption energy should be in the appropriate range. Therefore, improving the bond energy between the catalyst and intermediate species by appropriate means can effectively promote the catalytic performance [31]. As for the OER, from the perspective of thermodynamics, the four electron transfer steps are all uphill reactions driven by additional energy input. In addition, the energy barrier of each reaction is related, and the correlation is called the proportional relationship [32]. According to this relationship, the sum of the energy required for MOHads → MOads step (Eq. (1–4)) and MOads → MOOHads step (Eq. (1–5)) roughly equals ~ 3.2 eV. Therefore, if MOHads → MOads shows relatively low energy barrier under the catalysis of specific electrode materials, then the energy barrier of MOads → MOOHads step would be relatively high, and vice versa. When the energy required for MOHads → MOads and MOads → MOOHads is equal, the needed overpotential is minimized. 3 Modification strategies for electrocatalytic water splitting It is well known that the intrinsic activity of each site is the most important factor for electrocatalytic performances. Generally, the intrinsic activity is influenced by active site, conductivity, reaction energy barrier and electronic configuration. In detail, the more active sites in electrocatalysts can ensure more robust reaction activities [33]. Further, the better conductivity is favorable for faster electron transfer [34]. And the optimized reaction kinetics achieved by lowering the energy barrier can also improve the intrinsic activities [35]. Also, the modified electronic configuration can improve the catalytic activities at the atomic level [36]. Accordingly, the current modification strategies are mainly provided to optimize these key factors [37]. In the following parts, we mainly focus on the theoretical and experimental progresses about these strategies. 3.1 Element doping As is well known, element doping had been considered as an effective strategy to improve electrocatalytic activity of transition metal-based materials. As pointed by Zhang et al., with the rational modification of element doping, the intrinsic activity could be enhanced powerfully [37]. Thus, it is meaningful to get a deep horizon into the element doping strategy for the design of robust electrocatalysts. A comprehensive doping strategy is considered, and it is divided into three aspects for further discussion, including anion doping, cation doping, and anion/cation co-doping. First, recent studies show that anion doping can tailor the surface electronic structure to optimize the adsorption/desorption of the intermediate medium [38]. For example, Yao et al. used the NH4HCO3 as reactants to introduce N for anion doping in CoS2 [39]. Through the density functional theory (DFT) calculations shown in Fig. 2 (a and b), the authors revealed that the N-CoS2 tended to adsorb polar H2O molecule because N-CoS2 had more positive charge than pristine CoS2. The optimized ΔG H2O* and ΔG H* in N-CoS2 could collaboratively boost the HER and OER processes. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 2(c), N doping can effectively optimize the location of d-band center in N-CoS2, thereby reducing the binding energy between the catalyst and the adsorbent. In view of that F elements have higher electronegativity than phosphorus (2.19), sulfur (2.58) and nitrogen (3.04) elements, F doping could be a promising strategy for modulating electronic structures. The previous researches reported that using the NH4F as reactant to realize effective F doping. For instance, He et al. reported the F anion doped Ni2S3 nanosheet array on Ni foam (F-Ni3S2/NF) [40]. The obtained F-Ni3S2/NF electrocatalyst showed a superior HER activity in an alkaline solution. The good performance could result from that the F dopant accelerate the HER process. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) results indicated that the F-anion can modulate the electronic structure of Ni3S2. Moreover, the Gibbs free energies of water adsorption (ΔG H2O*) and hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H*) for F-Ni3S2/NF were lower than those of Ni3S2. Therefore, it indicated that there existed a strong electronic coupling between Ni3S2 and F anion, which optimized the hydrogen adsorption, thus accelerating the electrocatalytic process. Except for tuning the electronic structure, the anion doping has many merits such as efficiently increasing the active sites and improving the electric conductivity. The good electric conductivity and more active sites in the host materials can improve the efficiency of hydrogen generation [41]. For example, Liu et al. selected P as the dopant to improve the intrinsic electric conductivity and generate more active sites of MoS2 for enhancing the HER activity [42]. Furthermore, the P doped MoS2 can increase the interlayer spacing for accelerating the hydrogen adsorption and release processes. The density of states (DOS) results showed that P dopant can shorten the bandgap and increase the electronic states at the Fermi level, hence increasing the intrinsic electric conductivity of MoS2. Due to the above advantages, the P doped MoS2 only needs a small overpotential of 43 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 for HER electrocatalysis. Besides anion doping, introducing anion with an alloying effect could affect the electronic structure of the surrounding atoms on a large scale, leading to improved electrocatalytic performance. The anion alloying usually means utilizing alloying elements to modify the base material to a high degree, which accompanies with the generation of new phase. Both anion doping and anion alloying work through the interaction between the foreign atoms and surrounding atoms, which could affect the electronic structure of the base material. For instance, Jin et al. reported a ternary pyrite-type CoPS as HER electrocatalyst through substituting non-metal elements [43]. DFT calculations indicated that the ΔG H* at Co sites of CoPS is more favorable than that of CoS2. Moreover, the author found that the neighboring Co site became spontaneous after the spontaneous hydrogen adsorption of the open P site, reaching a ΔG H* equivalent to Pt. The change of ΔG H* is ascribed to that the neighboring Co3+ sites can be reduced to Co2+ and then back to Co3+ during the subsequent hydrogen adsorption process. As expected, the CoPS only needs a low overpotential of 48 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2 with 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte. Similar to the anion doping, metal cation doping also played an important role in electrocatalysis water splitting [44]. Recent work demonstrated that the cation doping can tune the electronic structure for optimizing the adsorption energies, resulting in efficiently enhancing the intrinsic activity of catalysts [45]. Considering the adsorption energies tuned by foreign metal doping, multi-metal catalysts usually have more favorite electrocatalytic activity than single metal catalysts. For example, Wang and his group incorporated zirconium metal cation into spinel structured oxide of CoFe2O4 as efficient electrocatalysts towards both HER and OER [46]. The authors found that the introduction of Zr could facilitate the electronic conductivity and induce the charge transfer between Fe and Zr. Apparently, the DOS results supported the above conclusion, which showed that the Zr substitution reduced the band gap and caused impurity state around the fermi level. Besides, the CoFeZr oxides also had favorite free energy along with OER pathway. Considering the semiconductor or insulator materials with unsatisfactory electronic transport, it had been found that the construction of metallic electrocatalysts is more conducive for hydrogen generation. In view of these, metal cation doping could be a promising strategy to achieve the electronic structure engineering. Liu et al. achieved transforming the typical semiconductive characteristics of pyrite NiS2 into metallic characteristics through V cation doping [47]. The X-ray absorption spectroscopy results indicate that the V doping can induce the electron around V atoms transferring to Ni sites, resulting in that the Ni sites obtain more electrons. The charge-density contour map (Fig. 2(d)) distinctly exhibited that the lower charge density around V atoms, suggesting that the electron transfer was formed from V dopants to around atoms. Furthermore, the DOS calculations (Fig. 2(e)) revealed that the V doping into NiS2 achieved an apparent zero band gap, indicating metallic characteristics because of V doping. The metallic nature brought by V doping can enhance the electrocatalytic performance. As a result, the V doping leads to a low overpotential of 110 mV for HER at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH solution. Besides single anion or cation doping, anion and cation co-doping could also achieve satisfying electrocatalytic performances by the synergistic effect [48]. For instance, Qiao and his group demonstrated that the Fe and O modified Co2P catalyst (CoFePO) showed excellent electrocatalytic performances in both HER and OER process. Experimental results showed that the CoFePO catalyst possessed better electrocatalytic performances than other samples, which exhibited 87.5 mV for HER and 333.5 mV for OER at 10 mA cm−2. It indicated that the anion and cation modulation made a huge contribution in improving catalytic performance. On the other hand, Yan et al. reported a callistemon like Zn and S co-doped CoP nanorod as robust electrocatalyst for overall water splitting [49]. The method can efficiently improve the electronic conductivity and tune the electronic structure for catalyst. Experimental results indicated that the Zn and S co-doped CoP exhibited excellent electrocatalytic performance (67 and 391 mV for HER and OER at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M phosphate-buffered solution). Through DFT calculations, the authors revealed that the Zn and S co-doping could optimize the adsorption free energy of intermediates by regulating the electronic structure. Thus, the improved HER and OER electrocatalytic performances could be obtained. In summary, element doping can effectively tune the electronic structure of adjacent region, which further optimizes the adsorption of reactants or intermediates. In addition, element doping also plays an important role in improving electronic conductivity of electrocatalysts. Thus, rational modification of element doping can effectively improve the intrinsic activity of electrocatalysts. 3.2 Phase engineering Modifying the intrinsic electrocatalytic activity through regulating and controlling the species and types of phase is a promising way. Specifically, Zhang et al. have demonstrated that the phase modulation could effectively change the oxidation state and thus optimize surface adsorption energy for spinel type electrocatalysts [50–53]. Besides, S. Qiao et al. and R. Wu et al. have also demonstrated the high efficiency of designing crystalline-amorphous mixed phases towards water splitting respectively [54,55]. Generally speaking, much of the work focused on the following several aspects: (1) Designing and constructing pure amorphous phase; (2) converting amorphous phase into crystalline phase; (3) designing and regulating allotrope. Due to the unordered bonding, weaker bonding energy, and the existence of much dangling bond, pure amorphous phase naturally contains rich defects [56–58]. This makes them more benefit for the adsorption of OH* and the formation of OOH*, thus the amorphous phase usually outperforms their crystalline counterparts towards OER catalysis. Recently, controlling the amorphous state in various substances is widely studied by researchers to achieve the high activity towards overall water splitting. For example, there are researchers utilizing amorphous phase to enhance active species. Cai et al. obtained the amorphous nanocages of Cu-Ni-Fehydr(oxy)oxide through utilizing a rapid photocorrosion method [59]. The obtained sample showed the low overpotential of 224 mV at 10 mA cm−2. The enhanced performance could be attributed to the increased active species in the amorphous nanocages. As is shown in Fig. 3 (a), with the photocorrosion process going on, the amorphous degree increased. Notably, through the XPS spectra, the authors revealed an increased Ni3+/Ni2+ ratio as well as the higher ratio of O2 (O in NiOOH) to O3 (O in Ni(OH)2) after the photocorrosion. It indicated that the amorphous state contained much more Ni(III/IV) active species, which led to the enhanced OER performance. Besides, there are also researches controlling the transformation from amorphous phase to crystalline phase. For example, Masa et al. adopted an idea to convert the amorphous Co2B into partially crystalline state by annealing under different temperatures [60]. The good performance could be attributed to that the boron induced lattice stress, which thermodynamicly and kineticly facilitated the hydroxylation reaction. Thus, rate determining step of OER could be accelerated. As shown in Fig. 3(b and c), the bond distances of the optimal sample were larger than those for the other reference, indicating that some degree of strain was introduced into the lattice by boron. This could be helpful to accelerate the formation of OOH* active species in the OER, therefore the catalytic performance achieved obvious improvement. Besides, some researchers utilized the surface reconstruction of amorphous phase to achieve superior OER catalysis. For instance, Yu et al. reported a scalable synthesis of amorphous NiFeMo oxide with uniform elemental distribution through a simple co-precipitation method [61]. The amorphous NiFeMo oxide showed the low overpotential of 280 mV at 10 mA cm−2 towards OER catalysis in 0.1 M KOH. The authors pointed out that the satisfying performance could be mainly indexed to the subsequently formed NiFe-OOH surfaces with rich oxygen vacancies. The surface reconstruction led to the lower work function, and DFT calculation proved that the oxygen vacancies could reduce the ΔG by ~ 0.26 eV at Fe sites, which meant the accelerated desorption of O2 from the *OOH. Through above discussions, it should be noted that the two seemingly contradictory aspects of constructing pure amorphous phase and transforming amorphous phase indeed have their scopes respectively. The pure amorphous phase usually benefits the material system which demands for plenty of defects, such as oxide and hydroxide typically. Meanwhile, the transformation from amorphous phase to crystal would be greatly helpful for inducing the lattice stress. And typically, the boride system particularly suits this strategy, due to the special role of boron atoms. Another way is to take full advantage of the properties of allotropes. Wang et al. used NH4HCO3 to introduce guest ions (NH4 +, CO3 2−) for intercalating the layers of MoS2 [62]. During the hydrothermal process, 1 T or 2H phases could be obtained by controlling the reaction temperature. The final optimal sample was the mixed phase of 1 T and 2H MoS2, and the presence of 1 T phase could bring in more active sites and better conductivity for the HER. Moreover, the mix with 2H phase could be beneficial for stabilizing the metastable 1 T MoS2, preventing the restacking as well as the conversion to 2H phase. Thus, the 1 T/2H MoS2 possessed the satisfied HER performance as well as good stability. Furthermore, Yang et al. synthesized the vertically arranged 1 T-MoS2 by using self-templates of exfoliated 2H-MoS2 [63]. The unique MoS2-based homostructures not only increased the exposure of active sites, but also improved the mass transfer owning to the introduction of high contact zone area. The final all-MoS2 electrocatalysts exhibited a superior HER activity. As a result, the hierarchic multiphase MoS2 possessed a satisfying performance. On the other hand, Hu et al. designed the β/δ-FeOOH through the controlled solvothermal methods [64]. The α, β, δ and their mixed phases were achieved by selecting different anions. The results showed that the β/δ-FeOOH displayed the utmost OER activity in the alkaline water. The partial density of state (PDOS) calculation revealed that due to the Jahn-Teller effect, much lattice distortion appeared, which donated more active sites. Especially, the oxygen vacancies could further speed up the separation of H atom from OH*, which corresponds to the step of OH* + OH− → O* + H2O + e−. Thus, the improved OER catalytic activity could be attained. Despite the already achieved transformation between amorphous and crystalline, as well as the design and regulation towards allotropes or crystals, there still exists a lack of observations towards the phase evolution during the catalytic process. There is no doubt that the change in phase of catalyst would significantly influence the catalytic reactivity and stability. The recently thriving operative techniques such as in-situ XRD and Raman spectra will pave a new way for tracking the evolution of active species, and provide in-depth directions for initial design and further prediction of validation process towards phase engineering. 3.3 Structure cooperation Constructing hybrid components to achieve structure cooperation is another promising way to improve electrocatalytic activity for robust electrocatalysts. Combining two and more different materials can efficient overcome the shortcoming of single material, and simultaneously incorporate unique properties of each one. The structure cooperation pays attention to the strength and advantage of each component, as well as their complementary advantage, which is also indicated by Zhang et al. [65]. Carbon based materials as promising candidates, such as carbon nanotube, graphene, and porous carbon, are widely employed to enhance the electrocatalytic performance for improving conductivity, solid machine stability, and ion/electron transport [66–68]. Structurally, 1D carbon nanotube possessed many potential in energy conversion field due to the fast electronic transport path, shortened diffusion length, and excellent mechanical stability [69,70]. In view of this, Wang et al. reported a three-dimensional carbon paper/carbon tubes/cobalt-sulfide (CP/CTs/Co-S) via a templated-assisted method followed by a step of electrodeposition [71]. In this unique nanostructure, Co-S nanosheets as active catalyst were wrapped on the skeleton of CP/CTs. The 3D carbonaceous substrate CP/CTs served as conductivity part, due to the high specific area, high conductivity, and robust machine stability. As a result, the rational designed hybrid components exhibited high activity as efficient electrocatalysts for overall water splitting. In addition, metal–organic frameworks (MOF) are promising precursors for constructing porous carbon-based materials due to their inherent merits with high surface area and tunable pores. For instance, Weng and his co-author developed robust S-CoWP@(S,N)-C nanowires derived from (Co,W)-based MOF as HER catalysts. The obtained electrocatalyst consisting of S-CoWP nanoparticles were embedded in (S,N)-doped carbon matrix [72]. The DFT calculations revealed that the S-CoWP@(S,N)-C HER catalysts had a low ΔG H* of 0.050 eV, which was much lower than that of pure CoWP and graphitic carbon. This indicated that there was a structure cooperation effect between S-CoWP nanoparticles and carbon matrix, resulting in good HER performance. As a result, the S-CoWP@(S,N)-C composite catalysts displayed a robust HER electrocatalytic activity which only needed 35 and 67 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in acidic and alkaline mediums respectively. Apart from 1D carbon-based materials, 2D graphene nanolayers show excellent features including high electronic conductivity, large surface area, and unique morphology, making them compatible as supports for catalysts. Wang and his group constructed vertically oriented FeP nanowires on 2D reduced graphene oxide (rGO) [73]. The vertically grown FeP nanowires integrated with rGO sheets ensured the high intrinsic activity, enhanced electron transport, and sufficient active sites contacted with electrolyte. Benefiting from these advantages, the FeP/rGO showed better electrocatalytic performance than the FeP nanowires. In addition, Miao and his colleague developed rGO supported Ni-Mn-Co ternary oxide and sulfide hybrid components respectively as robust electrocatalyst for both OER and HER process in alkaline electrolytes [74]. For the OER process, the rGO supported Ni-Mn-Co oxide exhibited remarkable catalytic performance with a low overpotential of 320 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2, as well as good stability. The synergistic effects between the conductive rGO and highly active Ni-Mn-Co oxide promoted the OER process. Besides, the rGO supported Ni-Mn-Co sulfide only needed 151 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2. In virtue of DFT calculations, the Ni-Mn-Co sulfide possessed more favorite O–H bond breaking and Had adsorption energies. Further, Tang et al. reported a nickel cobalt hydroxide vertically assembled on the rGO surface (NiCo-HS@G) via a general coprecipitation strategy [75]. In this hybrid materials (Fig. 4 (a–c)), the graphene skeleton was employed as conductive supports for enhancing electron transportation and loading sufficient active substances. Besides, the vertically oriented NiCo-HS nanosheets provided enough space to promote gas evolution to ensure efficient mass transfer. Thus, the excellent catalytic performance was obtained. Except for carbon-based materials, introducing active materials is another way to combine each other based on their respective advantages. The hybridization of them shows a promising strategy for the construction of highly active electrocatalysts. As well known, the synergistic effects between two or multiple materials play an important role in boosting catalytic performance. Ji et al. reported a FeP2-NiP2 spherical nanocages encapsulated in P doped carbon as highly efficient electrocatalysts. The FeP2-NiP2@PC shows an excellent performance with an overpotential of 117 mV for HER in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 248 mV for OER in 1 M KOH. The excellent performance can be ascribed to the synergistic effects of high conductivity of P-doped carbon, highly exposed active sites of nanocage structure, and fast diffusion of porous structure [76]. On the other hand, hybridizing metal oxides and metal phosphides can give full play to their respective properties. For example, Huang et al. adopt a partially phosphatizing method to develop FeO x /FeP hybrid nanorods as high-performance catalyst for HER in neutral medium [77]. It had been found that the hybrid FeO x /FeP owned abundant interface edges due to the nanoscale crystal domains. Theoretical analysis results revealed that FeO at the interface were more favorable for the adsorption and dissociation of water in HER process. Besides, the Fe-O-P interface tuned the ΔG H* of FeP. As a result, the FeO x /FeP exhibited superior HER performance with a low overpotential of 96 mV for 10 mA cm−2, as well as good durability. Further, Wu and his colleague found that the NiO with rich oxygen vacancy possessed massive active sites for adsorbing water (Fig. 4(d)), while the Ni2P with negatively charged P species promoted the adsorption of hydrogen intermediates [78]. According to the experimental results, the hybrid NiP2/NiO displayed competitive performance with an overpotential of 131 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER process. This work opened a horizon for rationally designing metal phosphide and oxide hybrid components for efficient electrocatalysts. Beside the geometry effect, interface interactions can also influence the catalytic activity of hybrid materials. In addition, designing a rational core–shell structure also provided an efficient way to improve catalytic activity through interface effects. For examples, Zhu and his co-author developed core–shell Co9S8@MoS2 nanostructure/carbon nanofibers (Co9S8@MoS2/CNFs) [79]. The Co9S8@MoS2/CNFs hybrid components showed higher HER and OER performances than pure MoS2/CNFs and Co9S8/CNFs. The high activities of Co9S8@MoS2/CNFs were attributed to the synergetic effects of nanointerface brought by the direct contact of Co9S8 core and MoS2 shell. The DFT calculations (Fig. 4(e)) suggested that the nanointerfaces could reduce the kinetic energy barriers of H2 desorption on the surface of the hybrid components. And Jiao et al. reported a core-branch CoP@NiFe-OH hybrid components on the surface-phosphatized Ni foam (CoP@NiFe-OH/SPNF) [80]. When used as bifunctional electrocatalysts, the CoP@NiFe-OH/SPNF catalyst needed 1.53 V to achieve 10 mA cm−2 during the water splitting, exceeding the catalytic performance of noble IrO2||Pt/C. Further, theoretical and experimental results indicated that CoP@NiFe-OH/SPNF hybrid components had strong synergistic catalytic effects, resulting to accelerated HER and OER kinetics. Besides, the core-branch structure and self-supported electrode can bring massive exposed active sites, fast ion/electron transport and solid stability. Therefore, the CoP@NiFe-OH/SPNF catalyst displayed better catalytic performance than single CoP or NiFe-OH. Here, structure cooperation with different materials, including inert materials and active materials, is discussed. For inert materials, carbon-based materials are considered as promising candidates due to their high electronic conductivity, solid stability and enhanced ion/electron transport. On the other hand, the hybrid engineering with two different active materials can give full play to the characteristics of each component, as well as produce new effects. 3.4 Interface engineering Many subsequent studies have widely reported that nano-heterostructures can greatly improve the kinetic behavior of intermediate species reactions, owning to the strong electronic interaction at interfaces and synergy of each component. As illustrated by Zhang et al., the heterostructure and interfaces could be utilized as effective means for modifying electronic structure [81–84]. Compared with phase engineering, Zheng et al. have pointed out that both phase and interface engineering need to be premised on the combination or transformation of the different lattice structures [85,86]. However, the two strategies have obviously different concerns. Specifically, the phase engineering focuses on the transformation between amorphous and crystalline, as well as the design and regulation towards allotropes or crystals [54,87]. Meanwhile, compared with structure cooperation, as indicated by Zhang et al., the interface engineering focuses on the components of a strongly coupled relationship, which usually functions through the strong electronic interactions brought by interfaces [81,82]. The strongly coupled interface could bring in excellent functional effects such as the built-in electric field and electron structure tuning, which makes it compatible for application in electrocatalysis. In general, from the perspective of component, the heterojunction refers to the heterointerface between active species, or between the active species and the inert species. Notably, the heterointerfaces usually function through adapting the adsorption free energy of intermediate active species, or accelerating the transmission of electrons [88,89]. The acceleration of electron transfer means a superb electric conductivity, and the modification of the adsorption energy in fact means the facilitation of the water splitting reaction. Thus, the electrocatalytic activity can be regulated and controlled by interface engineering. For example, Zhu et al. developed the Co-Ni3N nanowires array through atomic epitaxial in-growth method, where a confinement effect was enhanced at the interface [90]. The Co-Ni3N heterostructure was formed by thermally annealing NiCo2O4 nanowires, where the low mismatching interface formed (Fig. 5 (a)). According to the DFT results, a lattice misfit no more than 5% is beneficial for fast electron transfer. In Fig. 5(b), the bader charge analysis affirmed that electrons was transferred from the Co to Ni cations near the interface, indicating that electrons traveled from Co to Ni3N, where Ni and Co centers at the interface received and gave electrons respectively. The accumulated electrons on Ni would stabilize the Had atom, which promoted the catalytic HER process. Further, the interface could also influence the distribution of electrons. Jia et al. demonstrated the hybrid NiFe LDH-NS@DG10 by combining NiFe LDH nanosheets with defective graphene [91]. The catalyst showed low overpotential of 0.21 V at 10 mA cm−2 towards OER. The satisfying performance could be mainly indexed to the redistribution of electrons at the interface between DG and NiFe LDH-NS. As pointed by the authors, the electron accumulated around the defect sites. The localized electrons accumulation at the defect sites was supposed to enhance the HER. At the meanwhile, the electron transfer resulted in the holes accumulation on NiFe LDH-NS, which was favorable to OER. As a result, the high activity towards both HER and OER could be achieved. There is also research utilizing the interface to change the coordination environment of active sites. Wang et al. developed a CoO x heterostructure which consisted of CoO x nanosheets further grown on the nanotube, inspired by plant leaves [92]. This CoO x nanosheets/nanotubes interfaces own highly active Co2+ sites towards efficient OER. As a result, this CoO x interfaces demonstrated a relatively satisfying OER activity. The satisfying performance could be primarily due to the Co2+ octahedral structure at the interface between CoO x . As is shown in Fig. 5(c and d), the shoulder peak at 781.1 eV is indexed to the crystal redistribution via the Co2+ octahedral construction (noted as Co2+ Oh). As can be seen from Fig. 5(e), the electrons in Oh structures are more likely activated into the conduction band. As is shown in Fig. 5(f), the PDOS of the Oh structure is computed, which reveals that the electrons of Co2+ Oh structure are more active. All these results reveal that the good conductivity brought by the Co2+ Oh at the interface plays the main role of improving the catalytic performance. Besides, the existence of interfaces would usually affect the adsorption energy of intermediate species. For example, Wu et al. reported the combination of Ni3N and NiMoN. The heterostructures could take advantage of each component to achieve the high efficiency of both HER and OER [93]. The nitridation on Ni-Mo-O was conducted utilizing NH3. Finally, the overpotential of 31 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for HER could be attained, almost catching up with Pt. The satisfying performance could be explained by the Fig. 5(g and h). The Ni3N-NiMoN interfaces possess the lowest adsorption free energy for H2O and H*, indicating the inchoative catalyst-H2O state could be effortlessly formed at the interface between Ni3N and NiMoN to boost the OER activity. From the above discussions, a conclusion could be reached that the key point of interface engineering is the strong electronic interactions induced by a proper lattice mismatch at the interface. Thus, species on either side of the interface are the fundamentals for interface designing. Besides, although various interfaces between different compounds have been designed and successfully applied for overall water splitting, there is still a lack of research on the evolution of interfaces during cycling service. Notably, the recently developed in-situ methods such as in-situ TEM would provide a new sight in related observations, and this would lead us to the further predictions of interface validation process. 3.5 Vacancy engineering Currently, the introduction of vacancies in electrocatalysts has become a key research topic, which can effectively modulate the intrinsic activities of electrocatalysts [94]. By definition, vacancy can be considered as the absence of atoms at the lattice sites [94]. In general, there are anion vacancies and cation vacancies. And some researches also prove the co-existences of cation and anion vacancies in one material system [95]. The experimental and theoretical investigations have demonstrated that vacancy engineering can increase the density of active sites, but also make sure the fast charge transfer by modifying the bandgap in electrocatalysts [95]. Further, vacancy engineering can also boost the reaction kinetics by optimizing the adsorption/desorption energy in HER or OER [96]. To sum up, it is vital to rationally engineer vacancies in electrocatalysts. Firstly, we will discuss the anion vacancies in transition-metal-based nonprecious nanostructured catalysts. According to the earlier literatures, there are many reported approaches to produce anion vacancies (O, S, P and Se), such as controlling calcination temperatures, controlling hydrothermal conditions, thermal reduction, electro-oxidation, laser modification, cation exchange strategy and plasma treatment [94,95]. Among these approaches, plasma treatment is considered as a promising and controllable strategy for modifying electrocatalysts, owing to the high efficiency, low cost, low gas temperature and environmental friendliness [97]. To date, Wang’s group pioneered to utilize plasma treatment for creating different kinds of vacancies in electrocatalysts [98–101]. Typical, Wang’s group reported that Co3O4 with rich oxygen vacancy was obtained by Ar plasma treatment, as shown in Fig. 6 (a) [98]. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area was increased from 95.27 to 160.26 m2 g−1 after Ar plasma treatment, indicating the more active sites. And the surface oxygen vacancies were also formed by Ar plasma, which created the new gap states, and thus the conductivity and OER activity of Co3O4 was improved. In addition, a new strategy by combining element doping and vacancy engineering is achieved by plasma treatment [102–104]. For example, Wang et al. utilized NH3 plasma to transform Co3O4 into N-doped Co x O y with rich oxygen vacancies, which showed a much lower overpotential of 280 mV for OER [102]. The similar improvement can be also found in NiO nanosheet arrays by N+-ion irradiation, where the oxygen vacancies and N doping coordinatively narrow the band gap, resulting in the improved conductivity and OER activity [103]. Further, Wang et al. utilized Ar plasma with P source to filling the oxygen vacancies in Co3O4 with P element [104]. DFT calculations demonstrated that the conductivity was improved by this facile strategy, leading to significantly enhanced HER and OER activities for Co3O4 [104]. Except for plasma treatment, the cation exchange is considered as another facile strategy to introduce oxygen vacancies in electrocatalysts. For instance, Qiao and his co-authors synthesized NiO nanorods (NRs) with oxygen (O) vacancies through this strategy [105]. The calculated density of states (PDOS) showed the forming new electronic states near the Fermi level (Fig. 6(b)), indicating the higher conductivity in NiO with oxygen vacancies. Consequently, the NiO NRs with oxygen-vacancy engineering showed an enhanced HER activity with a low overpotential of 110 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Furthermore, Cai et al. fabricated CoWO4− x @C nanoparticles with rich O vacancies, which was achieved by reduction reaction in H2 (10 vol% in argon) atmosphere [106]. The transition state of the H2 formation in CoWO4− x was significantly lower, indicating the better HER activity. While the unpaired electron in O atom led to a moderate barrier of Oads formation and O2 release, suggesting the enhanced OER activity. Apart from the oxygen vacancy, sulfur vacancy is another widely researched anion vacancy. For example, Jin and his co-authors fabricated mesoporous (holey) 1 T phase MoS2 nanosheets by a liquid-ammonia-assisted lithiation strategy [107]. Through the desulfurization reaction between lithium and MoS2, there are unique mesoporous with edge sites and a large concentration of S-vacancies on the surface. Consequently, as-obtained mesoporous 1 T phase MoS2 shows the superior HER performance. And Li et al. also utilized H2 plasma treatment to introduce a large amount of sulfur vacancies to amorphous MoS2 [108]. DFT calculations demonstrated that the ΔG H* in MoS2 with one sulfur-vacancy is close to zero, indicating the enhanced HER activity. And the overpotential for amorphous MoS2 is decreased from 206 to 143 mV at 10 mA cm−2 after H2 plasma treatment. Further, Voiry et al. systematically investigated the role of sulfur vacancies in MoS2 [109]. With the increase of S vacancy concentration, there are two stages including “point defects” at low S vacancy concentrations and rich undercoordinated Mo atoms (S stripping) at high S vacancy concentrations. Voiry et al. demonstrated that combing point defects and undercoordinated Mo region was the effective strategy to maximize the HER activity of MoS2 nanosheet [109]. Analogously, Sun et al. also engineered WSe2 with controllable selenium vacancies by annealing in different temperatures. By introducing the selenium vacancies, the basal planes in WSe2 can be efficiently activated and optimized, resulting in enhanced HER activities [110]. Furthermore, Feng and his co-authors also introduced Se vacancies and P displacements in CoSe2, where the synergistic effects could modify the electron structure and proton dynamic properties [111]. And Xia et al. used high-energy Ar2+ beam irradiation to introduce Se and Mo vacancies to MoSe2 nanosheet arrays [112]. Through DFT calculations, the authors revealed that the |ΔG H*| values for both Se and Mo sites are lower than those in pristine MoSe2, indicating the activated electrocatalytic sites. Therefore, the synergistic effects from multi-vacancies in MoSe2 give rise to the better HER activities. On the other hand, cation vacancies are also prevalent in electrocatalysts, which can be effectively altered the electrocatalytic properties. For examples, Wang and his co-authors introducing Cation Vacancies (Fe or Ni) in NiFe LDH by etching Al or Zn element, as illustrated in Fig. 6(c) [113]. After forming vacancies in NiFe LDH, Ni3+ (t2g 6eg 1) with an optimal orbital distribution is formed from Ni2+ (t2g 6eg 0), which can effectively promote electron transfer. And the electronic configuration can be optimized by forming eg orbital occupancy in Ni3+, leading to the enhanced OER activities for NiFe LDH. In addition, Zou et al. investigated the effects of Co vacancies on Co3− x O4, which was fabricated by calcining cobalt acetate at different temperatures [114]. Based on X-ray absorption near edge structures (XANES), authors demonstrated that there were the lower Co coordination number and higher disorder in obtained samples, indicating the presence of rich Co vacancies in Co3− x O4. DFT results in Fig. 6(d) showed that the adsorbed energy (E ads) of water in Co3− x O4 was lower than that in Co3O4, indicating the Co vacancies was beneficial for H2O adsorption in OER. Consequently, Co3− x O4 showed an enhanced OER performance with a low overpotential of 268 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Moreover, Zhang et al. also reported ultrathin δ-FeOOH nanosheets with rich Fe vacancies through a wet-chemistry strategy [115]. By XANES analysis, the coordination number for the Fe-Fe in δ-FeOOH was reduced to 1.6, suggesting the presence of abundant Fe vacancies (VFe). After introducing VFe, there are rich second neighboring Fe (Fe2 site) to Fe vacancies. For HER process in δ-FeOOH, DFT results in Fig. 6(e) indicated the neighboring Fe2 site possess the optimal ΔG H*, suggesting the improved HER activity. For OER in Fig. 6(f), the theoretical overpotential on Fe2 site is decreased to 0.46 V, indicating the enhanced OER activity. Therefore, δ-FeOOH with abundant Fe vacancies showed the superior HER and OER performances. Meanwhile, electrocatalysts with both anion and cation vacancies are also demonstrated to boost the intrinsic activities for electrocatalysts in a synergistic way [116–118]. For example, Wand and his co-authors reported ultrathin CoFe LDH by exfoliating corresponding bulk by Ar plasma [101]. And results showed the O, Co, and Fe vacancies are introduced by Ar plasma, which enhanced the OER performances of CoFe-LDH. Further, Sun et al. fabricated NiFe LDH with multiple vacancies through the memory effect [116]. Typically, the oxygen and metal vacancies were introduced by hydration of the calcined NiFe-LDH, which could enlarge the number of active sites, improve the conductivity and boost the reaction kinetics [116]. 3.6 Strain engineering Recently, strain engineering provides a novel strategy in tailoring the electronic structure and electrocatalytic performances for electrocatalysts [119–121]. In electrocatalysts, strain is generally limited to elastic strain including tensile strain and compressive strain, which can recover on the stress removal [119]. And Li et al. also summarized the methods to induce strain in electrocatalysts, such as morphology modulation, lattice mismatch and controlling substrate [119]. In the following part, a brief introduction about strain engineering is given, which is utilized to tune the electrocatalytic performances. For example, Qiao et al. demonstrated that the strain engineering was an effective strategy to improve the intrinsic activity of CoO in HER [122]. In detail, Qiao et al. fabricated CoO nanorods (NRs) by the cation exchange process, and the strain induced by cation exchange was mainly present on the surfaces. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), DTF results demonstrate that strain plays a key role in lowering the ΔG H* values in O-vacancy-rich {111}-O surface. Impressively, an optimal value of ΔG H* can be achieved with 3% strain in CoO NRs. In addition, the O 2p-band in CoO is upshifted after introducing 3% strain, leading to the more covalency in Co-O bonding and the weakened H adsorption (Fig. 7(b)). Therefore, strain engineering can effectively modify the electronic structure and optimize ΔG H*, resulting in improved intrinsic HER activity for CoO. As shown in Fig. 7(c), the fabricated CoO NRs possess the superior HER activity, which is competitive among noble and non-noble metals. Further, a large number of efforts have been paid to transition metal chalcogenides with strain engineering, especially for MoS2 [123–125]. From the theoretical aspect, Yu et al. demonstrated that the free energy and charge transfer in monolayer Ni-MoS2 could be modified by straining engineering [125]. As shown in Fig. 7(d), the calculated ΔG H* is decreased to 0.02 eV with 10% tensile strain. When the tensile strain increases from 10% to 11%, it can be found the semiconductor-to-metal transition in Fig. 7(e). Consequently, DFT results demonstrate that strain engineering in monolayer Ni-MoS2 can lower the ΔG H* and enhance the charge transfer, thus leading to the improved catalytic performance. For practical application, Zheng et al. developed a strain technique by nanostructured rigid substrate, which could manipulate the ΔG H* and Fermi level in the MoS2 basal plane [126]. By using this technique, tensile strain is applied to MoS2 with sulfur vacancies (denoted as V-MoS2). DFT calculations show that the increased tensile strain can induce bands to gradually approach the Fermi level (Fig. 7(f)), which effectively narrows the band gap and increases the number of gap states. After electrochemical tests, monolayer MoS2 shows the poor HER activity, indicating the main presence of the inactive basal plane in obtained MoS2. After introducing S vacancy and strain to MoS2 (denoted as SV-MoS2), the much enhanced HER activity can be observed. Therefore, formation of strained S vacancies in MoS2 is grounded in the engineering of the HER activities in MoS2. Further, Zheng et al. utilized the scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM) to detect the strained S vacancies on MoS2 [127]. By determining the extracted kinetic parameters of formal potential and electron-transfer rate constant, Zheng et al. demonstrated that strain engineering could indeed accelerate the HER kinetics. At present, the overall-water-splitting performances are greatly limited by the poor OER activity, which is mainly attributed to the more sluggish kinetics [8,10]. In particular, strain engineering is gaining increased attention on enhancing the OER activities. For example, Jeon et al. fabricated core-shelled Mo2C-MoS2, which is obtained by annealing S coated Mo2C in the presence of MoCl5 [128]. And there is 3.45% tensile strain in MoS2, which is owing to the bent MoS2 for conforming Mo2C. In this core–shell structure, MoS2 sheets with lattice strain can provide rich active sites for OER, while Mo2C as an electron conductor can make sure the fast electron transfer. Consequently, core-shelled Mo2C-MoS2 shows the low overpential (280 mV at 10 mA cm−2) for OER, which is superior to pristine MoS2. Therefore, it has been shown that strain engineering can effectively modify the intrinsic activity for HER and OER. And strain engineering is generally combined with other modification strategy (such as vacancy and hybrid components) to achieve a synergistic effect for improving their electrochemical performance. 3.7 Self-functionalization Recently, self-functionalization behaviors have been reported in recent researches, which are the auto-oxidation during HER or OER process [129–134]. Specifically, Zhu et al. has made inspiring illustrations about the transformation of surface phase and intermediate species during catalytic process, from the perspective of in-situ characterization [135–137]. In the HER or OER process, ultrathin oxides or hydroxides can be in-situ formed on the surface of transition metal based catalysts, which can provide abundant active sites and also serve as protective barrier for further oxidations. Besides, the adsorption and desorption of intermediate active species could also be influenced. Therefore, self-functionalization with proper design or engineering is considered as a new strategy to improve the electrochemical performances and durability. For HER, Zhang et al. synthesized thin Ni3S2 films on nanoporous copper substrates (Ni3S2@NPC), as shown in Fig. 8 (a) [129]. The as synthesized Ni3S2@NPC electrocatalysts showed superior HER catalytic performances and excellent stability, as shown in Fig. 8(b). Further, the authors pointed out that the satisfying performances of HER catalysis resulted from the O2 involved self-activation process, where the morphology reconstruction and the surface chemically active film formed. The newly constructed porous morphology and active surface film benefits the exposure of active sites and the mass transfer during the catalytic process, thus, the electrode suggested a self-enhanced properties. Furthermore, the deep explorations towards self-functionalization were conducted through in-situ XPS characterization by Luo et al. [130] The authors successfully fulfilled the synthesis of Mo2C particles decorated MoS2 microspheres, which indicated remarkable HER catalytic performances with low overpotentials of 227 mV in acid and 220 mV in alkaline at 1000 mA cm−2. The improvement of HER catalytic activities was mainly attributed to the self-oxidation of Mo2C during catalytic process, where chemically active oxygen groups were in-situ formed. As shown in Fig. 8(c and d), as the potential increased, the oxygen species on the β-Mo2C surface changed from −O to −OH. As is revealed by the further DFT calculations, this self-functionalization process modified the electron distribution and facilitated the gas evolution of β-Mo2C, thus the satisfying performances were achieved. When it comes to OER catalysis, Zou et al. proposed a boronization strategy towards various metal sheets to obtain electrochemically active and stable electrodes [131]. Typically, during the OER process, a thin amorphous film of metaborate-containing oxyhydroxide would be in-situ formed. As a result, the as obtained boronized Ni sheet showed the obviously enhanced OER catalytic performance after the self-functionalization, which could be mainly attributed to the improved charge transfer and intermediate species adsorption energy brought by the newly formed highly active film. Furthermore, Han et al. utilized DFT calculations to further quantify the self-functionalization process [132]. The authors firstly achieved the preparation of Co1− x Ni x S2 nanoparticles on the graphene, which suggested a better performance after the self-functionalization in OER. This improvement originated from the partial oxidation on the surface of Co1− x Ni x S2 nanoparticles, which could be further confirmed by Fig. 8(e and f). There exists an optimal oxidation degree to be stable, and after the formation of thin oxidation layer, the free energies of four electron transfer steps all decreased to a relatively low level. This means that the self-functionalization could effectively modulate the adsorption of OH groups, as well as the conductivity. Besides, the Han et al. made deep explorations towards the self-activation of CoNiS species during OER utilizing the DFT calculations [133]. As shown in Fig. 8(g), the partial amorphization occurring on the surface benefitted the modification of OER pathway. Finally, a low overpotential of 290 mV at 10 mA cm−2 was achieved, due to the synergy of crystalline–amorphous interfaces formed in the self-functionalization process. Despite the progresses mentioned above, there are still a lot of spaces for deeper exploration towards self-functionalization. Most researches have focus on the improvements brought by the in-situ formed chemically active film, however, only few quantified the effects of functionalization degree. It seems that the amount of newly formed active species would change during the catalytic process, so the in-depth exploration of quantifying the influence suggests great significance. In-situ characterization provides new sights for these related studies, and this will benefit for the further predictions towards the validation process of self-functionalization. The performances of electrocatalysts involved in modification strategies are summarized in Table 1 . It could be seen that the involved material systems are mainly Fe, Ni, Mo or Co based compounds, which could be due to that the rich valence states of these elements provided plenty of room for modification of electronic structure. For HER electrocatalysis, there are already modified non-noble electrocatalysts achieving catalytic performance comparable to platinum [39,40,72,93]. While for OER electrocatalysis, the majority of modified non-noble metal compounds could only achieve the overpotential of more than 250 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which suggests that there is still rich room for reducing the OER overpotential. Besides single modification strategy, there are also many researches utilizing the combination of different modification strategies to obtain the obvious improvement towards the catalytic performances [91,102,128]. For instance, the cooperation of hybrid and interface engineering [91], doping and vacancy engineering [102], doping and strain engineering [128] has suggested great potential for constructing cost-effective electrocatalysts. So the synergy of modification strategies could play a key role in the next stage of electrocatalyst development. In addition, the stability is also an important index for evaluating the actual service potential of the electrocatalyst. However, we did not list them here, due to that the current evaluation methods for the stability is not particularly strict. Under most cases, the test period of chronopotentiometry is more than 10 hours. However, there may be test period of more than thousand hours [134], while other test period is tens or hundreds of hours. So the periodic index of chronopotentiometry is not uniform, and thus, we suggest the potential decay rate per 10 hours (P dr10) to be the general index of stability evaluation. It can be calculated as following: P d r 10 = ( P 10 - P 0 ) / P 0 , where P 0 and P 10 represent the potential of chronopotentiometric curve at initial moment and ten hours later, respectively. This would be a stricter index, which could be helpful for the comparison of stabilities among different materials and researches. The stricter stability evaluation index will greatly promote the research on the stability of electrocatalytic materials (the validation process of modification as mentioned above), and finally would be conducive to the actual application of modified transition metal based electrocatalysts. 4 Conclusions and perspective In summary, this review has discussed and concluded the modification strategies for improving the intrinsic activities, which may provide some new understandings on transition metal-based electrocatalysts for electrocatalytic water splitting. From the theoretical and experimental results, these modification strategies including element doping, phase engineering, hybrid components, interface engineering, vacancy engineering, strain engineering and self-functionalization are demonstrated to boost the reaction kinetics and improve the intrinsic activities. Despite these developments and progress, several challenges are still remaining: (1) Doping engineering is a hot research direction in electrocatalytic water splitting domains. With the enormous works made by the researchers, element doping is mainly used in tuning the electric structure, improving electronic conductivity, and increasing active sites exposure. However, it is very important to reveal the true active centers of dopant in the host materials during the catalysis process. Further, the effective doping strategies to avoid the lost of dopants in electrocatalytic process can bring great help to the durability in practical application. (2) As for phase engineering, there are already quite mature analytical testing methods for the allotrope, but there still remains difficulties for the specific and in-depth characterization of amorphous phase. Besides, there is still plenty of room for the quantitative study of the components in amorphous state. It is worth noting that the combination of surface analysis and bulk analysis will play a great role in the future researches. (3) As for structure cooperation, massive researches are devoted to improve electronic conductivity and utilize synergic effects between several kinds of materials. However, the real catalytic process and catalytic mechanism of electrocatalysts are really important in the advancement of hybrid components. Thus, devoting much works on this aspect with the help of in situ/operando technologies may benefit for the development of hybrid materials. (4) About the interface engineering, current studies have made detailed and in-depth exploration of the interface between the active components, finding that the interface plays an important role by optimizing the adsorption free energy of the intermediate active species and accelerating the electron transfer process. However, few studies focus on the interface between active species and inert substrate. Noteworthily, the exploration of this might be a key leading to the deeper understanding for the nature of various functions at the interface. (5) As for vacancy engineering, it is vital to enrich the kinds of electrocatalysts with different vacancies for highly efficient water splitting. And the in-depth understandings on how vacancies work in HER or OER process are still needed further investigation, which may strongly require the in situ or operando techniques. Further, the new and scalable approaches for generating vacancies in a short time, especially for a large amount of vacancies, are strongly desirable, which may show great potentials in practical applications. (6) As for strain engineering, more efforts are suggested to extend the promising catalysts, especially for OER or bifunctional catalysts for overall water splitting. And the in situ or operando techniques are desirable for characterizing the reactions, which may provide some in-depth understanding of the strain on electrocatalysts. Further, the excellent activities can be expected by the synergistic effects of different factors in complicated electrocatalysts. And more attention is suggested to be paid on the role of each factor by DFT modeling. (7) During the catalytic process, the surface of the sulfide and carbide would usually be oxidized, whether under HER or OER process. The crystallinity of as-formed oxide thin film is often low, containing many defect sites, which may bring in the improvement towards the intrinsic electrocatalysis activities. Herein, we classify this type as ‘self-functionalization’, and there are already many researchers making relatively deep explorations towards this section from both experimental and theoretical aspects. However, the origin of the oxidation during HER process is still confused, and more explorations are needed to further determine whether the oxidation is due to dissolved oxygen or intermediate species. The answer to this question would greatly benefit the controllable application of ‘self-functionalization’ strategy. (8) More attention should be paid to the stability of non-noble metal based catalysts. The current stability evaluation index is not strict enough, here we suggest the potential decay rate per 10 hours (P dr10) to be the general index of stability evaluation. The stricter stability evaluation index will not only be helpful for the comparison of stabilities among different materials and researches, but also be conducive to the actual application of modified transition metal based electrocatalysts. Yaotian Yan received his Master’s degree in 2020 and is currently pursuing his Ph.D in the State Key Laboratory of Advanced Welding and Joining, Harbin Institute of Technology,. His research interests focus on energy electrocatalysis, including electrocatalysts design and water splitting. Pengcheng Wang received his B.S. degree from Harbin Institute of Technology in 2018. He is currently pursuing his Ph.D. degree under the supervision of Prof. Jicai Feng at the Harbin Institute of Technology. His research interests are focused on the electrocatalytic water splitting and lithium/sodium ion battery. Jinghuang Lin received his Ph.D. in Materials Processing Engineering from Harbin Institute of Technology. His research interest focuses on the design and construction of high-performance catalytic nanomaterials. Jian Cao is a full professor at State Key Laboratory of Advanced Welding and Joining, Harbin Institute of Technology (HIT). He received his B.S. and Ph.D. degrees under the supervision of Prof. Jicai Feng from Harbin Institute of Technology in 2002 and 2007, respectively. In 2014–2015, he was a visiting scholar at the research group of Prof. Xiao Ping in University of Manchester, where he was mainly engaged in the research on the interface structure control of new materials and dissimilar materials. Now, his research focuses on surface-interface behavior, nanointerfaces, and surface modification. Junlei Qi is a full professor at State Key Laboratory of Advanced Welding and Joining, Harbin Institute of Technology (HIT). He received his B.S. and Ph.D. degrees under the supervision of Prof. Weitao Zheng from Jilin University in 2005 and 2010, respectively. He was a visiting scholar in Prof. Toriumi Akira's group (2012–2013) at the University of Tokyo, where he investigated single-crystal graphene micro–nano device manufacturing. Dr. Qi’s current interests focus on vertical-standing arrays for electrochemical energy storage and conversion.

coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic water splitting driven by electrocatalysts is recognized as a promising strategy to generate clean hydrogen fuel. Searching and constructing high-efficient and low-cost electrocatalysts is vital in the practical applications of electrocatalytic water splitting. Although transition metal-based materials have been considered as promising electrocatalysts, the satisfactory activities are usually not built on the bulk materials, but strongly relying on elaborately designing these electrocatalysts. Herein, the recent theoretical and experimental progress on modification strategies to improve the intrinsic activities is summarized, especially including element doping, phase engineering, structure cooperation, interface engineering, vacancy engineering, strain engineering and self-functionalization. Finally, the future opportunities and challenges on these modification strategies are also proposed. Overall, it is anticipated that these modification strategies offer some new understandings on rationally constructing non-noble electrocatalysts for efficient electrocatalytic water splitting.
